headline.main: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL

byline.original: By Sandra Gardner SOME parents who have been accused of molesting their children say they are victims of a new style of child-custody war - one in which vengeful former spouses charge them with sexually abusing their children as a way to eliminate visitation or gain sole custody.   ''That's what you get in South Jersey, when you get a divorce, you get charged with sex abuse,'' said Margaret E. Allen of Burlington City.   Miss Allen is the co-founder of the New Jersey chapter of VOCAL (Victims of Child Abuse Laws) and the fiancee of Christopher Clauss, who was arrested and charged with molesting his then 2 1/2-year-old daughter on May 4, 1984. (The final divorce decree was granted May 14.) Mr. Clauss was later found not guilty in a Burlington County trial.   Miss Allen said that the charges against Mr. Clauss had stemmed from visitation difficulties with his former wife.   ''And you automatically lose your visitation rights,'' she said, ''and that's the way you lose custody, when you're charged with this.''   Miss Allen said that 90 percent of the 76 members of New Jersey VOCAL were involved in custody or visitation battles, had recently become involved with a new partner, or both. The chapter, formed in February 1985, was patterned after a group in Minnesota (there are reportedly 65 chapters in the country).   The New Jersey group is mostly male, but does include a few women accused of molestation and girlfriends and wives of men in the group. (Nearly all have been charged with abusing their own children, but some have been accused of molesting children they live with.) Miss Allen said that the state Department of Human Services' Division of Youth and Family Services, whose mandate is to protect children, did not follow proper procedure in investigations.   The division's actions, Mr. Clauss said, ''smack of Nazi Germany in 1933 and the McCarthy era.''   Geoffrey S. Perselay, the acting Human Services Commissioner, said of VOCAL: ''I'll quote from Shakespeare: 'Thou dost protest too much.' ''   ''There is a big difference,'' he said, ''between being 'not guilty' and being found 'not guilty' by a court, with the limitations on testimony. For example, the ability of a 2-year-old child, often your best witness, to express itself as to what occurred.''   ''It's frustrating as hell to sit here,'' he said, ''cloaked in confidentiality, being under court order not to disclose particular facts of a case, with no opportunity to defend ourselves. It's difficult enough to prosecute these cases and protect children, and then you have a group like this, trying to detract focus from the children.''   Senator Catherine A. Costa, Democrat of the Seventh District (parts of Burlington and Camden Counties), who has been meeting with members of VOCAL, said: ''It's a very serious situation. A lot of these people are really hurting bad. In some instances it's a means of gaining custody. It's a sad situation - extremely cruel. Full justice has to rise to the surface in cases of innocence.''   Elderly people, women with young children, the handicapped and the poor will have problems getting their food, nutrition, and health needs met when the Middlesex County Board of Social Services moves to the outskirts of New Brunswick from the downtown area, says Enrico De Gironimo, assistant coordinator of Community Outreach Program for Senior Adults, a Rutgers community mental-health agency, and a member of the central New Jersey Rainbow Coalition.   The coalition - comprising social workers, community activists and recipients of social services -has been protesting the move.   ''A lot of these people are walk-ins, or take the bus downtown,'' said Mr. De Gironimo, ''and it's part of the 'hidden agenda' of the New Brunswick gentrification effort to drive the poor out of sight.''   The lease on the social services building is held by Rutgers, which plans to take it over for its Mason Gross School of the Arts in June 1987; Rutgers, in turn, is being forced out of its present site for the school.   The recent decision to place the county's social services in a leased building on Route 27, bordering Franklin Township, was made by the county freeholders and the Board of Social Services. However, financing and decisions for the board are dictated by the freeholders, according to Mary L. Hollis, director of the Board of Social Services.   ''There will probably be some clients who will have some difficulty in getting there,'' Mrs. Hollis admitted. ''We have a considerable number of clients who walk in.''   According to Dorothy K. Power, deputy director of the Middlesex Board of Chosen Freeholders, ''there will be no hardship.''   ''It's a 3 1/2-mile trip to the edge of town,'' she said, adding, ''We could have gone to Edison or Metuchen.''   Mrs. Power said the county was considering providing a small bus to pick up clients. ''Or they could mail things in, or call,'' she said. As for putting up a building in downtown New Brunswick, Mrs. Powers said, ''It would not be commercially feasible and there would be no parking spaces for the workers and the clients.''   Quentin Smith, a community consultant for the New Brunswick Outreach Center, a private nonprofit social-service agency, and spokesman for the coalition, said that the group was investigating the possibility of a class-action suit and would also use political and ''street'' tactics to deal with the issue.   ''Since they - the city and county policy makers - are making us, the poor and minority groups, uncomfortable - we'll have to make it difficult and uncomfortable for them, in terms of pickets and boycotts,'' Mr. Smith said. ''Additionally, we're planning a political response, when the coalition organizes its October convention, in terms of strategy for the 1986 election campaigns.''   Do you know the ''New Jersey connection'' for Lillian Moller Gilbreth, Carrie Bamberger Frank Fuld, Virginia Apgar, Ruth Cheney Streeter and Fanny Brice?   You can find the answers - and a lot more about many other women (53 in all) - in ''Eastern Her Story, 1986 Engagement Calendar,'' just off the press from Planned Parenthood of Northwest New Jersey, based in Morristown.   The 125-page book is filled with biographies of famous and not-so-famous contemporary and historical women in the Eastern states who have made contributions in the arts, sciences, government and other walks of life.   Decisions on whom to include were based on representation in geography, race, ethnic group, career, past and present figures, as well as proportions of well-known women and ''finds,'' as Jeff Brand, executive director of the Planned Parenthood affiliate, put it.   The calendars, which will be sold at $8.95 to raise funds, ''were a natural, in terms of celebrating contributions made by American women, and, at the same time, producing income for a women's health organization,'' Mr. Brand said.   For those who would like to get to know their ''finds'' a bit more, ample bibliographic material is provided.   ''We need to institutionalize our concern for the young,'' says State Senator Leanna Brown, Republican of Chatham.   Mrs. Brown, whose 26th District takes in parts of Morris and Passaic Counties, proposes to accomplish this by forming a new standing Senate committee on children. She plans to introduce a resolution calling for such a committee in the next legislative meeting.   ''When you have a standing legislative committee, you have hearings and linkages of how various programs can help,'' Mrs. Brown said, explaining that bills affecting children are now assigned to many committees and often get side-tracked in the bureaucratic maze.   For instance, she cited her own bills: One deals with discrimination against families with children in rental housing, the other creates an ombudsman for children. Both measures have not progressed.   A committee on children would be part of a three-pronged approach to children's issues, said Mrs. Brown. The proposed Governor's Commission on Youth and Families (recommended by an executive children's policy committee) would function as a recommender of policies; an ombudsman would follow the proposals through, at the executive level, and the legislative committee would implement legislation on children's issues.   A new standing committee can be created by resolution or by the more complicated change in rules, which would most likely not take place until the beginning of a new session

key_0.snippet: Intersex is a group of conditions where there is a discrepancy between the external genitals and the internal genitals (the testes and ovaries). The older term for this condition, hermaphroditism, came from joining the names of a Greek god and god...
key_0.lead_paragraph: Intersex is a group of conditions where there is a discrepancy between the external genitals and the internal genitals (the testes and ovaries). The older term for this condition, hermaphroditism, came from joining the names of a Greek god and goddess, Hermes and Aphrodite. Hermes was a god of male sexuality (among other things) and Aphrodite a goddess of female sexuality, love, and beauty. Although the older terms are still included in this article for reference, they have been replaced by most experts (and patients and families) because they are misleading, confusing, and insensitive. Increasingly this group of conditions is being called disorders of sex development (DSDs).

headline.main: Intersex

key_4.snippet: China executed two men Thursday morning for abducting and selling 15 children, many of them taken as babies or toddlers, the official Xinhua news agency said Friday. One of the men, Hu Minghua, 55, was convicted of kidnapping and selling nine chil...
key_4.lead_paragraph: China executed two men Thursday morning for abducting and selling 15 children, many of them taken as babies or toddlers, the official Xinhua news agency said Friday. One of the men, Hu Minghua, 55, was convicted of kidnapping and selling nine children. Five of the children, all boys now 3 to 6 years old, have been returned to their families, while the parents of the remaining ones have not been found. The other man, Su Binde, 27, was convicted of abducting six children. Five of those children were rescued by the police, while a sixth remains missing. Child trafficking is a big problem in China, where the traditional preference for male heirs and a restrictive one-child policy have driven a thriving market in baby boys, who sell for much more than girls. Girls and women are abducted and often used as laborers or as brides for unwed sons.
key_4.abstract: China executes Hu Minghua and Su Binde for abducting and selling 15 children, many who were taken as babies or toddlers; five children, all boys, have been returned to their families; child trafficking is big problem in China, where traditional preference for male heirs and one-child policy drive thriving market for boys (S)

headline.main: China: 2 Executed For Child Abductions

key_5.lead_paragraph: A man was arrested this weekend for questioning in connection with a series of child molestations in the San Fernando Valley, the police said. They said the man fit a composite of the suspect but warned that the case was not solved. At least 32 children, male and female, have been assaulted or nearly assaulted in the past two months, most as they walked to school, the police said. At least one rape occurred. The police have until Tuesday to decide whether to seek charges.

headline.main: Arrest in Child Molestations

key_5.snippet: To the Editor:   Re "Companies Merge; Families Break Up" (Op-Ed, Sept. 3): Lester C. Thurow correctly points out that the decline in men's wages is a major cause of family change. But he implies that the answer to family break-up and child neglect...
key_5.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re "Companies Merge; Families Break Up" (Op-Ed, Sept. 3): Lester C. Thurow correctly points out that the decline in men's wages is a major cause of family change. But he implies that the answer to family break-up and child neglect is to shore up male wages and restore the "traditional" family. While better jobs for all is a desirable goal, returning to a system of male breadwinning is an unworkable and, for many families, undesirable solution.

headline.main: Corporate Giants Tighten Their Hold on U.S.; Homemaker Nostalgia

key_6.lead_paragraph: Sophia says of her baby boy, ''I didn't know that I could ever love anyone this much.'' As a mother of four and a grandmother of eight, I understand her feelings. Those who are appalled that an older woman wants to bear a child saw nothing amiss when Tony Randall and Ben Bradlee fathered trophy children with women young enough to be their daughters or granddaughters.
key_6.abstract: Lee De Cesare letter comments on Oct 26 Lisa Belkin article on pregnancies among older women; says women have same right as men to have children late in life (S)

key_7.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your report on a drop in child abuse deaths in New York City could lead readers to believe things are getting better for abused and neglected children (news article, Dec. 2). They are not. In 1991 and 1992, almost three-quarters of the children whose deaths were listed as "homicides" lived in troubled families known to the Child Welfare Administration.

key_9.snippet: I could get a marriage license tomorrow that would sanction my relationship with any one of my male friends. No one would ask if we intended to raise children together, grow old together or any of the other things that supposedly ''sanctify'' marr...
key_9.lead_paragraph: I could get a marriage license tomorrow that would sanction my relationship with any one of my male friends. No one would ask if we intended to raise children together, grow old together or any of the other things that supposedly ''sanctify'' marriage. And we would instantly earn the rights of all married couples. But the one person whose relationship with me truly is a marriage -- with whom I'm raising a child, with whom I intend to grow old -- is the one person who would be turned away at the clerk's office if we applied to be ''married.'' Roseann Foley Henry Brooklyn

headline.main: What's Their Real Problem With Gay Marriage? (It's the Gay Part)

key_9.snippet: To the Editor:    Of the five dads who commented in the article, four were caring for children at or over preschool age. Many women, after a brutal financial calculation, conclude that any income they earned from working would be canceled out by f...
key_9.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Of the five dads who commented in the article, four were caring for children at or over preschool age. Many women, after a brutal financial calculation, conclude that any income they earned from working would be canceled out by fees for preschool or child care programs. They therefore stay at home, preferring to spend time with their growing children.

headline.main: Life as the Only Man in the Room at the P.T.A.

key_9.snippet: To the Editor:     Recent developments that would allow expectant parents to choose their baby's sex (front page, Sept. 9) open troubling questions over whether a company developing these techniques should be allowed to decide whether parents who ...
key_9.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Recent developments that would allow expectant parents to choose their baby's sex (front page, Sept. 9) open troubling questions over whether a company developing these techniques should be allowed to decide whether parents who already have two or three children of the same sex have a more valid right to choose the sex of their next child than parents who don't already have children.
key_9.abstract: S Rebecca Holmes-Farley letter, commenting on September 9 article, says method developed by researchers at Genetics & IVF Institute allowing parents to choose sex of child raises troubling ethical questions (S)

headline.main: Who Should Decide The Sex of a Baby?
